Blurb
Overview
This module is a 12-day residential field course that usually takes place in late August/early September. Students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental and survey design through a mixture of formal lectures, tutorial discussion groups, staff-led field visits and group research projects in the field. The field course also introduces students to a range of conservation projects and gives students the opportunity to interact with conservation biology/zoology professionals in the field.

The activities in this module are mainly based on field work, carried out by groups of students. Learning focussed on conservation is supported by conservation site visits, interaction with conservation practitioners, discussions/ debates and directed and self-directed reading. The planning, execution, analysis, interpretation and write-up of the field experiments and surveys are supported by lectures, seminars, discussions and tutorials. Together, these field-based activities address the following topics:

• Human-wildlife conflict and rewilding
• Approaches for successful conservation of animal species and their habitats/ ecosystems
• Fieldwork survey techniques and field data collection methods
• Experimental and survey study design in the field, including review of appropriate statistical techniques
• Team-based conception and development of scientific projects in the field
• Analysis and interpretation of data from field studies
• Communication skills: scientific report writing
• Communication skills: oral presentation
Educational Aims
This module seeks to develop in students:

• Proficiency in a diverse range of field survey techniques and sampling protocols, as well as team-working skills such as project conception/ development and management, coordinating responsibility for collecting data and communicating findings as a team.

• An understanding of the types of data that can be collected, sampling protocols and how to perform appropriate statistical analyses, and interpretation of data and results.

• The skills necessary to understand and synthesise information and present scientific information in the form of both an oral presentation and a written report.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to apply their theoretical understanding of zoology in stimulating and varied field-based settings, to acquire new field-based survey skills and to master the scientific process from project inception, through data collection and analysis to results communication. The module is a residential field course that usually takes place in late August/early September, prior to the start of Level 6, and lasts for 12 days. Students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental and survey design through a mixture of formal lectures, tutorial discussion groups, staff-led field visits and group research projects in the field. The field course also introduces students to a range of conservation projects and gives students the opportunity to interact with conservation biology/ zoology professionals in the field. It is assessed by continuous assessments. All scheduled activities take place during the residential field course, but optional tutorials to provide feedback on data analysis and report writing are offered on campus during Semester 1.
Outline Syllabus
The main topics covered by this module will include:

• Human-wildlife conflict and rewilding
Including: origins of human impacts on the environment, human-wildlife conflicts, alternative paradigms for conserving and restoring biodiversity, ecosystem complexity and emergent properties, rewilding.

• Approaches for successful conservation of animal species and their habitats/ ecosystems
Including: in-situ conservation, monitoring of populations of conservation concern, captive breeding and population supplementation, species reintroduction, management of threats to focal populations, management of human-wildlife conflicts, habitat management, restoring human-impacted ecosystems, restoring trophic structure and ecosystem complexity.

• Fieldwork survey techniques and field data collection methods
Including: approaches for evaluating the ecology of field sites and their habitats/ ecosystems, standard techniques for estimating the abundance, diversity and distribution of animals and plants in the field, measurement of abiotic conditions, spatial mapping of observations.

• Experimental and survey study design in the field, including review of appropriate statistical techniques
Including: selecting sites and subjects for field-based surveys and experiments, appropriate replication of field studies, pseudo-replication and how to avoid it, taking account of “nuisance” environmental variation, testing hypotheses in the field.

• Team-based conception and development of scientific projects in the field
Including: Conceiving and refining ideas for scientific projects, understanding and dealing with logistical constraints, use of pilot observations/studies to explore and test ideas, team-based collaborative project development, forward planning for data collection and analysis.

• Analysis and interpretation of data from field studies
Including: choosing and using statistical methods for analysis of data from field projects, linkage of project design to planned analysis, correlation and causation, accounting for the influence of non-target variables.

• Communication skills: scientific report writing
Including: approaches to effective report writing, knowing your audience, developing a scientific narrative or “story”, linking aims and hypotheses to background context and interpretation, identification and communication of key results, using word limits to improve your prose.

• Communication skills: oral presentation
Including: approaches to effective oral presentations, knowing your audience, how to structure a scientific oral presentation, appropriate use of diagrams and images, delivery styles, effective use of text, effective use of colour, getting your key points across, take-home messages.

This module will develop field skills introduced in the Y1 field course, and general scientific communication skills developed in Y1 and Y2 to an advanced level. In addition, this module will introduce new themes that have not been developed earlier in the Zoology Programme: on human-wildlife conflict (exemplified through conservation projects which the students visit), practical conservation of animals and plants in the field, principles of designing zoology studies (both experimental and observational) and independent project design, inception and execution.

Key literature supporting the module will be available through Canvas. Equipment to carry out fieldwork will be provided and transported to the field centre for use in the field. Discussions, lectures and site visits will be delivered from the field centre, using lecture/ AV facilities there, and in the field. All other materials supporting the module (including logistical and field course planning information, health and safety) will be available via canvas.

Students will be expected to engage with all aspects of field course planning and organisation/ preparation in a timely way, via email and return of information and paperwork to teaching staff. In addition students will be required to engage with and review/ read required reading and asynchronous content necessary to prepare the students for field working.

Students will be expected take an independent and responsible approach to learning and participation in this module: sourcing their own supplementary reading, studying the context and theory underpinning conservation projects, self-motivating and acting as effective team players to undertake fieldwork and take part in discussions and presentations, communicating constructively and supportively with peers and teaching staff, and acting as responsible representatives of the University of Liverpool ensuring their own safety, and acting in an environmentally responsible and ethical way.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning on this module are delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research connected teaching – Liverpool Curriculum Hallmark). The learning activities are constructively aligned to the programme learning outcomes and assessments. Students develop into independent learners, with critical thinking, reflection, and problem-solving skills. Teaching methods are lectures, structured discussions and debates, asynchronous learning material and fieldwork. Students will spend most of their time during the field course engaged with field work. Lectures, asynchronous learning, discussions before and during the course will maximise the value of the field-based activities and equip students to communicate the findings of their field work.

Teaching methods: Lectures (7 hours)

Description: A small number of lectures and seminars covering background and theory in rewilding, human-wildlife conflict, experimental/survey design and analysis and oral and written presentation skills
All lecture content will be enriched with opportunities for active learning including small-group break-out discussions, problem solving tasks, polls, and Q & A sessions.

Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Attendance Recorded: Yes, but since this is in the field records will be paper-based in case of poor internet connectivity. Student contribution to group-based fieldwork will also be captured through Peer Assessment.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment is in three parts: (i) approach and contribution to the field course (15% weighting), (ii) oral presentation (groupwork) communicating the findings of the field study (15% weighting) and (iii) scientific report on the field project (70%).

(i) Approach and contribution to the field course

During the field course we will assess each student's individual practical performance and contribution to the field course (approach and technique). We will do this by assessing information presented in the field notebook, and by assessing individual contributions to all aspects of the field course. Each student's approach and technique will be assessed by comparing their contributions with a rubric. This rubric-based method for documenting practical performance has already been tested successfully in previous residential field courses delivered in the School of Life Sciences, and a similar system has been used in assessing practical performance in Honours research projects. Rubric components relate to record keeping and field notebook (assessed by inspection of the field notebook or electronic record), general participation/ engagement (appropriate use of field gear, adherence to health and safety aspects, adherence to code of conduct, timeliness; assessed jointly by the teaching team at the end of the field course), group working in the field (assessed by the staff member supervising the group) and contribution to debates, lectures, seminars, site visits (assessed jointly by the teaching team at the end of the field course).

(ii) Oral presentation (group work)

The oral presentations on the field research projects will take place on the final day of the field course. Group members will be expected to contribute approximately equally to both the preparation and delivery of the talk. Although this is a group presentation and all members of the group are initially allocated the same mark, the grades will be weighted by individual contributions via peer assessment. Students will be expected to present their field research project including background and context, scientific rationale, methods and ethical considerations, results, conclusions and implications.

(iii) Scientific report

This will be a standard scientific report modelled on a Biology Letters paper, communicating the context, methods, results, discussion and conclusions of their field research project. Although students will have worked in groups to execute their projects, gather data and do data analysis in the field, the scientific report will be completed and marked individually.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios. Specifically, the assessments enhance digital fluency, problem-solving, teamwork, scientific communication, and critical thinking skills highly sought by graduate employers. (Digital fluency, Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

All assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught in the field setting through both targeted lecture and learning content and by ‘learning by doing’. Data used will be obtained by the students during field sessions. (Authentic assessment, Research connected teaching, Digital fluency, Active learning, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Reassessment will be via an online field project in which students design a project based on a scenario provided to them, and then analyse data previously collected for that specific project when it was run in the field in the past (the student does not need to do fieldwork or collect data themselves). The reassessment mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Perform overseas fieldwork in a safe, respectful, ethical and sustainable way, being considerate of the needs of other students, of local culture, the needs and perspectives of local people and the pressures acting on the local environment.
 LO2 Maintain a clearly presented field record that logically documents the work completed on the field course, including site visits, lectures, discussions, field project development, data collection, data analysis, results, and any other information that may be of importance in interpreting data.
 LO3 Critically evaluate different strategies for conservation, via site visits, interaction with conservation professionals, lectures and seminars, teacher-directed and self-directed reading and discussion sessions.
 LO4 Design a statistically valid field-based sampling programme to obtain behavioural and/or ecological data, in a responsible, safe and ethical manner.
 LO5 Perform diverse methods for field surveys of animals and plants, and be able to apply the appropriate methods at the individual, population, and community/habitat levels.
 LO6 Execute simple experiments or observational studies in the field.
 LO7 Analyse data collected from the field-based scientific project using appropriate statistical techniques and draw appropriate interpretations from the results.
 LO8 Communicate the findings of the field-based scientific project using different presentational methods (including oral and written), tailoring information content, delivery and technical depth to the needs of the audience.
Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 E1 Global citizenship— This skill will be fostered by taking part in the field course in an overseas location, and understanding and behaving appropriately to the environmental and cultural values of that place.
Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 RE1 Problem solving and reasoning skills—This skill will be developed through the conception, development and testing of field project ideas, through the critical evaluation of conservation projects and via the contextualisation and interpretation of results.
 RE2 Verbal and written communication—Students will have opportunities to develop written and oral communication skills through group discussions, oral presentations and written assessments. In addition, this skill will be developed through an understanding of the constituent elements of strong arguments, and exercises in the deconstruction of the student's own arguments, as well as scholarly arguments within research papers.
 RE3 Critical thinking and problem solving—This skill will be developed in classroom debates focussed on human-wildlife conflict, through critical evaluation and reflection on the effectiveness of different approaches to conservation and through the conception and design of survey/ experimental studies in the field.
 RE4 Comprehend and use data effectively—This skill will be developed through teaching and discussion on the design of surveys and experiments and the use of statistical analysis to address scientific questions and hypotheses, and through the student’s analysis of their own field research data.
 RE5 Evidence based reasoning—This will be evident from the student’s critical evaluation of the effectiveness of conservation projects, and from the interpretations and conclusions they draw from their results.
 RE6 Solving problems in a systematic and creative manner—This skill will be developed in students through the design and refinement of their field research projects.
 RE7 Information retrieval and review—This skill will be evident in the way that students compare and contrast the effectiveness of different conservation projects, and in the information they present as background to their scientific projects.
Learning, Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LRE1 Time management and organisational skills—This will be evident in the students’ independent management of their field projects, their oral presentation and written assignment and by meeting scheduled timings for field-course activities and coursework deadlines.
 LRE2 Adaptability—will be fostered through the development and refinement of workable plans to carry out the field project in groups, and the division and management of project tasks within student groups.
 LRE3 Improving own learning/performance - Reflective practice—Students will have opportunities to improve their learning and performance through reflection on (i) their ideas for research projects, in discussions with teaching staff, (ii) feedback given following preliminary and summative oral presentations, and through pre-submission feedback on approach to the scientific report submission.
 LRE4 Independent-learning—This skill will be developed in students through their self-directed reading on the topics of the module, and through researching the background to their scientific project, which will be evident through the background/ introduction sections to their oral presentation and scientific report.
 LRE5 Digital skills—This broad set of skills will be developed through the students handling of data and data analyses, through interrogation of literature and use of online databases and through use of software to present and communicate results.
 LRE6 Ethical awareness—This skill will be developed through discussion of human-wildlife conflicts as they present in different conservation projects, through considering the ethical implications of different approaches to conservation, and though consideration of the potential environmental and cultural impacts of visiting another country with a distinct set of environmental and cultural values.
 LRE7 Team work—This skill will be developed through students working together to effectively plan, execute and communicate the results of their field projects.

Blurb
Overview
This module is a 12-day residential field course that usually takes place in late August/early September. Students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental and survey design through a mixture of formal lectures, tutorial discussion groups, staff-led field visits and group research projects in the field. The field course also introduces students to a range of conservation projects and gives students the opportunity to interact with conservation biology/zoology professionals in the field.

The activities in this module are mainly based on field work, carried out by groups of students. Learning focussed on conservation is supported by conservation site visits, interaction with conservation practitioners, discussions/ debates and directed and self-directed reading. The planning, execution, analysis, interpretation and write-up of the field experiments and surveys are supported by lectures, seminars, discussions and tutorials. Together, these field-based activities address the following topics:

• Human-wildlife conflict and rewilding
• Approaches for successful conservation of animal species and their habitats/ ecosystems
• Fieldwork survey techniques and field data collection methods
• Experimental and survey study design in the field, including review of appropriate statistical techniques
• Team-based conception and development of scientific projects in the field
• Analysis and interpretation of data from field studies
• Communication skills: scientific report writing
• Communication skills: oral presentation
Educational Aims
This module seeks to develop in students:

• Proficiency in a diverse range of field survey techniques and sampling protocols, as well as team-working skills such as project conception/ development and management, coordinating responsibility for collecting data and communicating findings as a team.

• An understanding of the types of data that can be collected, sampling protocols and how to perform appropriate statistical analyses, and interpretation of data and results.

• The skills necessary to understand and synthesise information and present scientific information in the form of both an oral presentation and a written report.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to apply their theoretical understanding of zoology in stimulating and varied field-based settings, to acquire new field-based survey skills and to master the scientific process from project inception, through data collection and analysis to results communication. The module is a residential field course that usually takes place in late August/early September, prior to the start of Level 6, and lasts for 12 days. Students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental and survey design through a mixture of formal lectures, tutorial discussion groups, staff-led field visits and group research projects in the field. The field course also introduces students to a range of conservation projects and gives students the opportunity to interact with conservation biology/ zoology professionals in the field. It is assessed by continuous assessments. All scheduled activities take place during the residential field course, but optional tutorials to provide feedback on data analysis and report writing are offered on campus during Semester 1.
Outline Syllabus
The main topics covered by this module will include:

• Human-wildlife conflict and rewilding
Including: origins of human impacts on the environment, human-wildlife conflicts, alternative paradigms for conserving and restoring biodiversity, ecosystem complexity and emergent properties, rewilding.

• Approaches for successful conservation of animal species and their habitats/ ecosystems
Including: in-situ conservation, monitoring of populations of conservation concern, captive breeding and population supplementation, species reintroduction, management of threats to focal populations, management of human-wildlife conflicts, habitat management, restoring human-impacted ecosystems, restoring trophic structure and ecosystem complexity.

• Fieldwork survey techniques and field data collection methods
Including: approaches for evaluating the ecology of field sites and their habitats/ ecosystems, standard techniques for estimating the abundance, diversity and distribution of animals and plants in the field, measurement of abiotic conditions, spatial mapping of observations.

• Experimental and survey study design in the field, including review of appropriate statistical techniques
Including: selecting sites and subjects for field-based surveys and experiments, appropriate replication of field studies, pseudo-replication and how to avoid it, taking account of “nuisance” environmental variation, testing hypotheses in the field.

• Team-based conception and development of scientific projects in the field
Including: Conceiving and refining ideas for scientific projects, understanding and dealing with logistical constraints, use of pilot observations/studies to explore and test ideas, team-based collaborative project development, forward planning for data collection and analysis.

• Analysis and interpretation of data from field studies
Including: choosing and using statistical methods for analysis of data from field projects, linkage of project design to planned analysis, correlation and causation, accounting for the influence of non-target variables.

• Communication skills: scientific report writing
Including: approaches to effective report writing, knowing your audience, developing a scientific narrative or “story”, linking aims and hypotheses to background context and interpretation, identification and communication of key results, using word limits to improve your prose.

• Communication skills: oral presentation
Including: approaches to effective oral presentations, knowing your audience, how to structure a scientific oral presentation, appropriate use of diagrams and images, delivery styles, effective use of text, effective use of colour, getting your key points across, take-home messages.

This module will develop field skills introduced in the Y1 field course, and general scientific communication skills developed in Y1 and Y2 to an advanced level. In addition, this module will introduce new themes that have not been developed earlier in the Zoology Programme: on human-wildlife conflict (exemplified through conservation projects which the students visit), practical conservation of animals and plants in the field, principles of designing zoology studies (both experimental and observational) and independent project design, inception and execution.

Key literature supporting the module will be available through Canvas. Equipment to carry out fieldwork will be provided and transported to the field centre for use in the field. Discussions, lectures and site visits will be delivered from the field centre, using lecture/ AV facilities there, and in the field. All other materials supporting the module (including logistical and field course planning information, health and safety) will be available via canvas.

Students will be expected to engage with all aspects of field course planning and organisation/ preparation in a timely way, via email and return of information and paperwork to teaching staff. In addition students will be required to engage with and review/ read required reading and asynchronous content necessary to prepare the students for field working.

Students will be expected take an independent and responsible approach to learning and participation in this module: sourcing their own supplementary reading, studying the context and theory underpinning conservation projects, self-motivating and acting as effective team players to undertake fieldwork and take part in discussions and presentations, communicating constructively and supportively with peers and teaching staff, and acting as responsible representatives of the University of Liverpool ensuring their own safety, and acting in an environmentally responsible and ethical way.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning on this module are delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research connected teaching – Liverpool Curriculum Hallmark). The learning activities are constructively aligned to the programme learning outcomes and assessments. Students develop into independent learners, with critical thinking, reflection, and problem-solving skills. Teaching methods are lectures, structured discussions and debates, asynchronous learning material and fieldwork. Students will spend most of their time during the field course engaged with field work. Lectures, asynchronous learning, discussions before and during the course will maximise the value of the field-based activities and equip students to communicate the findings of their field work.

Teaching methods: Lectures (7 hours)

Description: A small number of lectures and seminars covering background and theory in rewilding, human-wildlife conflict, experimental/survey design and analysis and oral and written presentation skills
All lecture content will be enriched with opportunities for active learning including small-group break-out discussions, problem solving tasks, polls, and Q & A sessions.
Attendance Recorded: Yes, but since this is in the field records will be paper-based in case of poor internet connectivity

Teaching methods: Seminars (8 hours)

Description: Structured discussions and debates. Discussion and critical evaluation of topic-relevant ecological papers and reports
Staff-led and student-led discussion will form the basis of these group sessions fostering critical thinking and confidence. The sessions will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore a greater breadth of issues, and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of different approaches to conservation and critical analysis of their efficacy.
Attendance Recorded: Yes, but since this is in the field records will be paper-based in case of poor internet connectivity

Teaching method: Fieldwork (70 hours)

Description: residential fieldwork
Working in small groups in the field in an international location is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches and uses the diversity of the student cohort and geographical location to enhance cross-cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality amongst the students and local residents and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Fieldwork allows students to develop real-world skills by learning and applying sampling and surveying techniques, experimental design, planning, time management, problem solving, critical thinking and collaborative working skills: all skills that are sought after in the graduate employment market. (Confidence, Digital fluency, Active Learning, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching methods: Groupwork (8 hours)

Description: Small group work to carry out field investigations, prepare for and deliver material in debates, discussions and oral presentations. Working in small groups is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches, and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Groupwork also promotes skills in team-based working and collaboration that are highly sought after in the workplace.
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement and contribution to the oral presentation (group) assignment monitored through peer assessment.

Teaching methods: Tutorial (3 hours)

Description: Small group tutorial involving field research project groups and teaching staff, aimed at providing formative feedback on preparation of the scientific report assignment.
Attendance monitored: No

Teaching methods: Self-directed learning (44 hours)

Description: Asynchronous recorded lecture/ active learning material; consolidation of taught material; preparation for taught sessions, discussions, debates and computer practicals; literature review, evaluation and synthesis to support taught sessions and assignments.
Asynchronous recorded lecture/ active learning material will consist of supplementary lecture content provided to broaden topic understanding and structure independent study, AO- and reading-associated learning tasks. This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for lectures, practicals or field trips. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. The preparatory material includes recommended reading/details/demonstrations of practical techniques used, field techniques, health and safety and any ethical implications and theoretical background. (Confidence; Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance Recorded: No, but engagement will be monitored via assessment of contributions to debates and discussions which require use of this teaching material

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Attendance Recorded: Yes, but since this is in the field records will be paper-based in case of poor internet connectivity. Student contribution to group-based fieldwork will also be captured through Peer Assessment.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment is in three parts: (i) approach and contribution to the field course (15% weighting), (ii) oral presentation (groupwork) communicating the findings of the field study (15% weighting) and (iii) scientific report on the field project (70%).

(i) Approach and contribution to the field course

During the field course we will assess each student's individual practical performance and contribution to the field course (approach and technique). We will do this by assessing information presented in the field notebook, and by assessing individual contributions to all aspects of the field course. Each student's approach and technique will be assessed by comparing their contributions with a rubric. This rubric-based method for documenting practical performance has already been tested successfully in previous residential field courses delivered in the School of Life Sciences, and a similar system has been used in assessing practical performance in Honours research projects. Rubric components relate to record keeping and field notebook (assessed by inspection of the field notebook or electronic record), general participation/ engagement (appropriate use of field gear, adherence to health and safety aspects, adherence to code of conduct, timeliness; assessed jointly by the teaching team at the end of the field course), group working in the field (assessed by the staff member supervising the group) and contribution to debates, lectures, seminars, site visits (assessed jointly by the teaching team at the end of the field course).

(ii) Oral presentation (group work)

The oral presentations on the field research projects will take place on the final day of the field course. Group members will be expected to contribute approximately equally to both the preparation and delivery of the talk. Although this is a group presentation and all members of the group are initially allocated the same mark, the grades will be weighted by individual contributions via peer assessment. Students will be expected to present their field research project including background and context, scientific rationale, methods and ethical considerations, results, conclusions and implications.

(iii) Scientific report

This will be a standard scientific report modelled on a Biology Letters paper, communicating the context, methods, results, discussion and conclusions of their field research project. Although students will have worked in groups to execute their projects, gather data and do data analysis in the field, the scientific report will be completed and marked individually.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios. Specifically, the assessments enhance digital fluency, problem-solving, teamwork, scientific communication, and critical thinking skills highly sought by graduate employers. (Digital fluency, Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

All assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught in the field setting through both targeted lecture and learning content and by ‘learning by doing’. Data used will be obtained by the students during field sessions. (Authentic assessment, Research connected teaching, Digital fluency, Active learning, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Reassessment will be via an online field project in which students design a project based on a scenario provided to them, and then analyse data previously collected for that specific project when it was run in the field in the past (the student does not need to do fieldwork or collect data themselves). The reassessment mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Perform overseas fieldwork in a safe, respectful, ethical and sustainable way, being considerate of the needs of other students, of local culture, the needs and perspectives of local people and the pressures acting on the local environment.
 LO2 Maintain a clearly presented field record that logically documents the work completed on the field course, including site visits, lectures, discussions, field project development, data collection, data analysis, results, and any other information that may be of importance in interpreting data.
 LO3 Critically evaluate different strategies for conservation, via site visits, interaction with conservation professionals, lectures and seminars, teacher-directed and self-directed reading and discussion sessions.
 LO4 Design a statistically valid field-based sampling programme to obtain behavioural and/or ecological data, in a responsible, safe and ethical manner.
 LO5 Perform diverse methods for field surveys of animals and plants, and be able to apply the appropriate methods at the individual, population, and community/habitat levels.
 LO6 Execute simple experiments or observational studies in the field.
 LO7 Analyse data collected from the field-based scientific project using appropriate statistical techniques and draw appropriate interpretations from the results.
 LO8 Communicate the findings of the field-based scientific project using different presentational methods (including oral and written), tailoring information content, delivery and technical depth to the needs of the audience.
Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 E1 Global citizenship— This skill will be fostered by taking part in the field course in an overseas location, and understanding and behaving appropriately to the environmental and cultural values of that place.
Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 RE1 Problem solving and reasoning skills—This skill will be developed through the conception, development and testing of field project ideas, through the critical evaluation of conservation projects and via the contextualisation and interpretation of results.
 RE2 Verbal and written communication—Students will have opportunities to develop written and oral communication skills through group discussions, oral presentations and written assessments. In addition, this skill will be developed through an understanding of the constituent elements of strong arguments, and exercises in the deconstruction of the student's own arguments, as well as scholarly arguments within research papers.
 RE3 Critical thinking and problem solving—This skill will be developed in classroom debates focussed on human-wildlife conflict, through critical evaluation and reflection on the effectiveness of different approaches to conservation and through the conception and design of survey/ experimental studies in the field.
 RE4 Comprehend and use data effectively—This skill will be developed through teaching and discussion on the design of surveys and experiments and the use of statistical analysis to address scientific questions and hypotheses, and through the student’s analysis of their own field research data.
 RE5 Evidence based reasoning—This will be evident from the student’s critical evaluation of the effectiveness of conservation projects, and from the interpretations and conclusions they draw from their results.
 RE6 Solving problems in a systematic and creative manner—This skill will be developed in students through the design and refinement of their field research projects.
 RE7 Information retrieval and review—This skill will be evident in the way that students compare and contrast the effectiveness of different conservation projects, and in the information they present as background to their scientific projects.
Learning, Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LRE1 Time management and organisational skills—This will be evident in the students’ independent management of their field projects, their oral presentation and written assignment and by meeting scheduled timings for field-course activities and coursework deadlines.
 LRE2 Adaptability—will be fostered through the development and refinement of workable plans to carry out the field project in groups, and the division and management of project tasks within student groups.
 LRE3 Improving own learning/performance - Reflective practice—Students will have opportunities to improve their learning and performance through reflection on (i) their ideas for research projects, in discussions with teaching staff, (ii) feedback given following preliminary and summative oral presentations, and through pre-submission feedback on approach to the scientific report submission.
 LRE4 Independent-learning—This skill will be developed in students through their self-directed reading on the topics of the module, and through researching the background to their scientific project, which will be evident through the background/ introduction sections to their oral presentation and scientific report.
 LRE5 Digital skills—This broad set of skills will be developed through the students handling of data and data analyses, through interrogation of literature and use of online databases and through use of software to present and communicate results.
 LRE6 Ethical awareness—This skill will be developed through discussion of human-wildlife conflicts as they present in different conservation projects, through considering the ethical implications of different approaches to conservation, and though consideration of the potential environmental and cultural impacts of visiting another country with a distinct set of environmental and cultural values.
 LRE7 Team work—This skill will be developed through students working together to effectively plan, execute and communicate the results of their field projects.
